title: Solskajer admits Marcus Rashford is burned out thanks to Manchester United's injury hell
text:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has admitted that he 'can't really give Marcus Rashford a break' due to Manchester United's limited options in attack.

Solskjaer has overseen the club's worst ever start in the Premier League and mounting injuries - plus the departures of Alexis Sanchez and Romelu Lukaku - has increased the dependency on Rashford.

Anthony Martial, the other primary attacking option, has had an extended spell on the sidelines and while Rashford looks to be fatigued physically and mentally, Solskjaer needs him to continue leading the line ahead of Sunday's crunch match against Liverpool.

Marcus Rashford is exhausted but cannot be rested, admits United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer

The Manchester United manager opened up on the workload that has been placed on Rashford

'At the moment we can't really give him a break because we've had injuries,' Solskjaer told Sky Sports pundit Gary Neville. 'Anthony [Martial] has been out for eight weeks now. So he's had to play loads more football than I'd hoped.

'Marcus is a centre forward who can play left, right and as a No 10. He wants to be able to play all the positions.

'I want him to be facing the goal, I want to be direct and attacking quickly, so at the moment I see him coming in off the left or as part of a two up front.'

The 21-year-old has found it tough to carry the weight of expectation to provide all the goals

Speaking to Gary Neville (left) before Sunday's game against Liverpool, Solskjaer opened up

MARCUS RASHFORD 2019-20 CLUB STATS Games: 10 Minutes: 803 Goals: 3 Assists: 2

Martial's absence seems to have particularly impacted Rashford's game, with the weight of expectation proving to be too much as United have struggled with the Frenchman out injured.

Rashford has scored just once from open play for United this season - three in total, with penalties against Chelsea and Leicester City - but did get a goal for England in the 6-0 rout of Bulgaria.

A return for Martial could see Rashford return to a wide role on the left, where he appears to be more comfortable, and while he will not be allowed to sit the game out, it may revitalise him after his goal in the international break.

Solskjaer knows at just 21, Rashford is still developing his game, and only because he arrived with a bang under Louis van Gaal as a teenager has expectation soared.

'Marcus' movement is great, but maybe we just need to give him a game or two of rest because he's played a lot,' Solskjaer added.

Anthony Martial has helped ease pressure on Rashford and the pair have a strong relationship

Martial plays as the side's No 9 due to his clinical finishing and he is set to return on Sunday

'Sometimes, because he's a young boy with lots of expectations on his shoulders, he's played four or five seasons now, and yet he's still not even 22 yet.

'He's a scorer of great goals, as he did for England. I want him to become a great goalscorer - and that's a different mentality. At the moment, he's learning his trade.'

United are slumped in 12th after the opening eight matches and know that defeat to rivals Liverpool at Old Trafford would see an 18-point gap open up between the two sides.
description: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has admitted that he 'can't really give Marcus Rashford a break' due to Manchester United's limited options in attack but accepts the forward is worn out right now.
